ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Martin, Please see my answers interspersed below. ... I would add a lot more caveats to that statement, but I think the spirit is right. If mutations

Hello Martin,

Please see my answers interspersed below. 

> > A second iss=
ue related to this list is that, because evolution tends to quickly select =
away mutations that deeply change representations, it is likely a good idea=
 to have something like the genomic diversity protection in NEAT. Because r=
ecent work has shown that phenotypic/behavioral diversity is more effective=
 than genotypic diversity, many people may be switching to phenotypic diver=
sity and abandoning genomic diversity: this work suggests that both may be =
important. For example, mutations that affect a representation deeply may i=
nitially hurt the organism's ability to do something behaviorally different=
/interesting, for the same reason that such mutations hurts fitness (e.g. t=
hey cripple the organism). Protecting that innovation for a while may thus =
pay off. 
> 
> I haven't read your paper yet. But following your argumentat=
ion, when profound differences in the genetic code have also a relatively l=
arge influence on the phenotype, protecting the phenotypic/behavioral diver=
sity should do the job!? 
> 

I would add a lot more caveats to that statem=
ent, but I think the spirit is right. If mutations tend to cause changes th=
at are initially deleterious, but that may recover to even higher fitnesses=
 than the pre-mutation fitness if allowed time for fine tuning, that is whe=
n protection will pay off. My guess is that deep changes to a representatio=
n fall into that category. My paper shows that evolution on its own (at lea=
st in our model) does not naturally protect such mutations, and that they a=
re thus rare. Evolution instead typically makes improvements via shallow, s=
urface-level mutations that do not change representation, but instead add n=
ew functionality onto the existing system. That results in a collection of =
hacks, instead of elegant, evolvable representations. 

> > In other words,=
 because selection will quickly work to eliminate deep changes, we should p=
robably protect them for a while if we want to see better representations e=
merge. 
> 
> I was wondering, whether it could be beneficial to protect phe=
notypic diversity in CPPNs (e.g. in HyperNEAT). Instead of measuring the si=
milarity of the genomes, the similarity of the produced patterns could be u=
sed to determine which individuals belong to which species. The idea is tha=
t relatively similar genomes can nevertheless produce differing patterns. S=
eparating them would allow to better exploit the potential of the same gene=
tic code. 
> 

That is a good idea, and one I have heard others (including =
Jean-Baptiste Mouret) suggest. The way I think about it is that there are t=
hree aspects to an organism (at least, in systems with generative encodings=
 like HyperNEAT): the genome, the phenotype (ANN), and the behavior. It wou=
ld probably help to encourage diversity in all three, assuming two things: =
(1) you have the computational resources to afford doing so, and (2) your a=
lgorithm does not perform worse with additional objectives. Unfortunately, =
(1) is not always true, and (2) seems to be false, even with our best multi=
-objective algorithms (e.g. NSGA-II). So, in practice, it becomes an empiri=
cal and often case-by-case question as to what type of diversity to encoura=
ge. I hope that more people conduct studies comparing the benefits includin=
g/excluding each of these three different types of diversity, so we as a fi=
eld can begin to get an empirical and general understanding of how benefici=
al their inclusion is. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Visiting Scientist
Corne=
ll University
